I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans of 
(i) up to $50,000,000 in United States (US) dollars to Arctic Green Energy Corporation Private 
Limited (AGE); and (ii) up to $200,000,000 equivalent in US dollars and yuan to Sinopec Green 
Energy Geothermal Development (SGE) for the Geothermal District Heating  Project in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project supports private sector participation in urban district heating with geothermal 
energy in the PRC. By facilitating the delivery of clean and reliable heating services, the project 
helps mitigate air pollution. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
3.  Heating is an important aspect of the PRC’s fight against air pollution and climate change. 
Approximately 25% of energy consumed in the country’s buildings is used to produce space heat; 
in the northern PRC, heating’s share is 50%. Heating needs are met primarily by cogeneration 
units, household stoves, and heat-only boilers, for which the share of coal as a feedstock is 
approximately  80%.1 This  has  severe  environmental  consequences,  as  particulate  matter 
produced from coal combustion is a primary cause of urban air pollution and is in turn associated 
with a range of serious health impacts and a reduction of economic output.2 Coal combustion is 
also a leading source of greenhouse gases (GHGs), of which the PRC is the world’s leading 
emitter, contributing directly to global climate change. 
 
4.  The  government  has  long  recognized  these  challenges,  and  has  placed  increasing 
attention on improving the environmental performance of the urban heating system. Policies 
issued by the Ministry of Environmental Protection instruct municipalities to close small-scale 
heat-only boilers and promote more energy-efficient technologies, including those based on 
renewable energy.3 Among the various options for more environmentally sustainable heating, 
geothermal energy has emerged as a new government priority.4 Geothermal energy offers stable 
temperatures (appropriate for heating), generates zero emissions, can be integrated into existing 
networks with other heat sources, and is economically viable (with adequate resources). When 
extracted fluids are reinjected, geothermal energy is also renewable. 
 
 
1  International Energy Agency. 2015. Building Energy Use in China: Transforming Construction and Influencing 
Consumption to 2050. Paris; and Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2013. Low-Carbon Development in Small and 
Medium-Sized Cities in the People’s Republic of China: Challenges and Opportunities. ADB Briefs. No. 14 (June). 
2  Pollution is estimated to reduce the PRC’s economic output by approximately 6% per year. Health Effects Institute. 
2016. Special Report 20: Burden of Disease Attributable to Coal-Burning and Other Major Sources of Air Pollution in 
China. Boston; and the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate. 2014. Better Growth, Better Climate: The 
New Climate Economy Report. Washington, DC.  
3  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Environmental Protection. 2017. Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action 
Plan. Beijing. 
4  Government of the PRC; National Energy Administration, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Land and Natural 
Resources, and the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development. 2013. Guiding Opinion Regarding the 
Promotion and Development of Geothermal Energy. Beijing; and Government of the PRC, National Development 
and Reform Commission. 2015. Enhanced Actions on Climate Change: China’s Intended Contribution. Beijing.

2   
5.  While  low-  and  medium-temperature  geothermal-based  heating  is  commonplace  in 
Europe and other regions, until the 2010s it occupied a limited niche in the PRC.5 Constraints to 
its development have included a lack of awareness of the country’s geothermal resource potential, 
gaps in technical expertise, a lack of relevant policies to spur adoption, and limited experience in 
the efficient management of heating networks. As a result, in 2015, geothermal energy (including 
both direct heating and ground source heat pumps) accounted for only 6% of the country’s heated 
floor space. However, the PRC’s low- to medium-temperature geothermal resource base is vast 
in terms of exploitable energy—at least four times the size of its natural gas reserve base. With 
advanced technologies and operational know-how, the PRC’s geothermal resources could be 
harnessed on a scale that would potentially heat several hundred cities. 
 
6.  In 2017, the government announced major initiatives to accelerate geothermal adoption 
in the heating sector. The National Energy Administration issued the country’s inaugural five year 
plan for geothermal energy, which targets a tripling of geothermal heating area to 1.1 billion 
square meters (m2) by 2020 and thereby the avoidance of 40 million tons per year of coal use.6 
The Ministry of Environmental Protection issued the Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action 
Plan, which calls for the replacement of coal-fired heating systems in 28 cities in the greater 
Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei (BTH) region7—the country’s worst-polluted area and home to nearly 30% 
of the population—with cleaner alternatives such as geothermal-based heating (footnote 3). 
Finally, the State Council launched the creation of a new economic zone in Xiong’an New Area, 
approximately 100 kilometers southwest of Beijing, involving the transfer of a significant portion 
of Beijing’s administrative and business activities to a new urban development of 2,000 square 
kilometers, and announced a decision to heat the area with geothermal energy.8 
 
7.  SGE, a Sino-Icelandic joint venture, is a leading proponent of geothermal district heating 
in the PRC. SGE is 49% owned by AGE, an Iceland-affiliated geothermal energy company. SGE 
utilizes advanced technologies, based on approaches transferred from Iceland (a country for 
which geothermal resources provide 69% of primary energy supply), and has a unique business 
model  spanning  upstream  and  downstream  operations.  Established  in  2006,  SGE  has  an 
operating portfolio of 25 cities and a large pipeline of identified opportunities. It collaborates with 
the government on national geothermal development plans, technology transfer and standards, 
and urban planning for Xiong’an.9 Recognizing the role of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
supporting  the  PRC’s  environmentally  sustainable  growth,  as  well  as  its  track  record  in 
nonsovereign assistance to pioneering urban infrastructure firms, AGE and SGE requested ADB’s 
assistance to scale up SGE’s operations. 
 
2.  Project Design 
8.  The project will support the construction, acquisition, rehabilitation, and operation of a 
series of urban district heating systems based on geothermal energy. ADB will extend financing

European Geothermal Energy Council. 2014. Developing Geothermal District Heating in Europe. Brussels. 
6  The target covers both ground-source heat pumps (0.7 billion m2) and direct heating (0.4 billion m2). Government of 
the PRC, National Energy Administration. 2017. Thirteenth Five-Year Plan for Geothermal Development. Beijing. 
7  The greater BTH region consists of Beijing and Tianjin municipalities; Hebei, Henan, Shandong, Shanxi, and Liaoning 
provinces; and Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. 
8  Xiong’an is designated as a national priority project. Completion of the core area of 100 square kilometers is targeted 
by 2022. The geothermal-based heat planned for the area will be provided by SGE. 
9  SGE has been providing heating services to Xiong’an since 2015. Around 70% of new heating area targeted under 
SGE’s business plan is located in the greater BTH region, encompassing Xiong’an and other areas.

3 
on a subproject-by-subproject basis, subject to defined environmental, social, development, and 
financial criteria.10 Subprojects will be identified during the project implementation stage. 
 
9.  Each subproject will involve a concession or similar public–private partnership (PPP) 
arrangement with a municipal government, under which SGE would have exclusive rights to 
develop geothermal energy resources and network infrastructure, and to deliver heat and related 
services  (e.g.,  hot  water)  to  residential,  commercial,  and  industrial  end  users.  Subproject 
infrastructure to be developed includes production and reinjection wells, heat centrals, monitoring 
and control stations, and heat trunk lines.11 At each location, the specific configuration of systems 
will depend on local development and environmental needs as determined by the municipal 
governments. Service fees, such as heat tariffs and connection fees, will be set by SGE and 
municipal authorities and adjusted as needed during operations. 
 
3.  Borrowers and Sponsors 
 
10.  Sinopec Green Energy Geothermal Development Company Limited. SGE or its wholly 
owned subsidiaries in Hebei and Shaanxi provinces will be the borrowers of the ADB onshore 
loan. SGE was incorporated in 2006 as a Sino-Icelandic joint venture to develop geothermal 
energy in the PRC. Established through the cooperation of the governments of the PRC and 
Iceland, it has grown to be the world’s largest geothermal districting heating company by service 
area.12 [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
11.  [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
12.  Arctic Green Energy Corporation Private Limited. AGE (offshore borrower and a 
sponsor) is an Iceland-affiliated company incorporated in Singapore to develop and operate 
renewable energy business in Asia. AGE’s primary focus is its PRC business, which is conducted 
solely through its shareholding and management role in SGE.13 AGE is wholly owned by its 
founder  and  executive  chairperson,  Haukur  Hardarson,  an  Icelandic  entrepreneur  with  a 
successful track record in renewables and other ventures.14 Beyond its role as sponsor and 
shareholder in SGE, AGE is also a conduit of leading geothermal technology and a key driver of 
SGE’s management. AGE has transferred Icelandic technologies in areas such as resource 
assessment, drilling, reinjection, and network controls, which have been successfully adapted by 
SGE for application in the PRC and are considered a core strategic advantage of the firm.15 
Technical  transfer  activities,  which  are  ongoing,  benefit  from  the  active  support  of  the 
governments of the PRC and Iceland.16 [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED]

with service exclusivity, (ii) compliance with ADB safeguards requirements, (iii) the exclusion of category A projects, 
(iv) incorporation of geothermal fluid reinjection, and (v) minimum thresholds for expected financial return.

4   
13.  Sinopec Group, a sponsor [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED], is a leading PRC 
oil and gas company. It is wholly owned by the State Council of the PRC.17 Shares of its major 
operating  subsidiary  Sinopec  Corporation  (also  known  as  China  Petroleum  &  Chemical 
Corporation) are publicly traded on the Hong Kong, London, New York, and Shanghai stock 
exchanges.18 Sinopec Group is rated A+ by Standard & Poor’s and A1 by Moody’s Investors 
Service. In addition to its conventional oil and petrochemical business lines, Sinopec Group is 
active in renewable energy, and has established the PRC’s National Geothermal Research and 
Technology Center under authority of the National Energy Administration. [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED]. 
 
14.  Integrity due diligence was conducted.19 No significant or potentially significant integrity 
risks were identified.20 ADB’s review of the entity does not give ADB cause to believe that such 
entity has been established, or is being used for money laundering, or terrorism financing in the 
jurisdictions involved in the project. Enhanced tax integrity due diligence on the transaction was 
also conducted.21 ADB’s review does not give ADB cause to believe that the transaction is being 
used for cross-border tax evasion. 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Output 
15.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: mitigated air pollution and GHG 
emissions in the PRC, consistent with the goals of the PRC’s Ministry of Environmental Protection 
(footnote 3). 22 
 
16.  Outcome.  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  expanded  provision  of 
environmentally sustainable heating services, which will provide clean, reliable, safe, and high-
quality heat to urban customers, and avoid GHG emissions. 
 
17.  Output. The output will be the construction of geothermal-based district heating systems. 
By 2021, (i) at least 20 municipal- or county-level PPPs will be developed, with the capacity to 
heat 50 million m2 of heated area; (ii) at least CNY7.9 billion will be spent domestically during 
construction; and (iii) at least 2,000 construction jobs will be provided.  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
18.  Consistency with ADB strategy. The project is consistent with ADB’s Midterm Review 
of  Strategy  2020,  which  identifies  (i)  environment  and  climate  change,  (ii)  infrastructure 
development, and (iii) private sector development as 3 of ADB’s 10 strategic priorities.23 With 
regard to the environment and climate change, the project mitigates air pollution and health 
threats and promotes clean energy. With regard to infrastructure, the project is aligned with 
Strategy 2020’s focus on environmentally sustainable growth. With regard to private sector 
development, the project supports a frontier area of private sector participation.

19.  Consistency with ADB country strategy. The project addresses  three of the five 
strategic priorities of ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020: (i) managing 
climate change and the environment (in the area of environmental sustainability and pollution 
control), (ii) supporting inclusive economic growth (in the area of inclusive and green cities 
development), and (iii) private sector development.24 With over 70% of SGE’s investment pipeline 
targeting the greater BTH region, the project complements ADB’s sovereign initiatives to address 
the region’s severe air pollution.25 
 
20.  Consistency with sector policies. The project directly supports two of the three pillars 
of ADB’s Energy Policy: (i) promoting energy efficiency and renewable energy (through the 
project’s support for geothermal energy), and (ii) promoting energy efficiency and renewable 
energy (through support to expansion and modernization of urban heating systems).26 The project 
also  supports  ADB’s  Urban  Operational  Plan,  2012–2020  in  the  plan’s  promotion  of  (i) 
inclusiveness (i.e., through affordable basic services), and (ii) environmental sustainability.27

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
22.  ADB’s proposed assistance to the borrowers consists of two loans to be funded from its 
ordinary capital resources: (i) a loan to AGE up to $50 million [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION 
DELETED]  and  (ii)  a  loan  to  SGE  up  to  $200  million  equivalent  in  US  dollars  and  yuan 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
23.  During the life of the loans, AGE, SGE, and SGE’s subproject companies will be bound 
by covenants stipulated in the loan agreements, including regular monitoring reports on finances, 
operations, and development effectiveness; and requirements to meet minimum financial ratios 
typical for this type of transaction. 
  
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
24.  ADB would add value through the following: 
 
(i)  as  ADB’s  first  private  sector  geothermal  district  energy  project,  the  project  is 
demonstrational  and  catalytic.  ADB’s  participation  in  the  project  is  expected  to 
establish more confidence in private sector participation in district heating PPPs in 
the PRC and the use of renewable energy in heating; 
(ii)  the  project  raises  standards  for  the  PRC  geothermal  industry  by  conditioning 
assistance  on  SGE  meeting  ADB’s  requirements  for  environmental  and  social 
management; and 
(iii)  ADB’s assistance will lower transaction costs by bundling a series of subprojects in 
multiple cities, which are often too small and time-consuming for local or international 
commercial banks to finance on a stand-alone basis.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
25.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified as 
category  B  for  environment,  category  B  for  involuntary  resettlement,  and  category  C  for

7 
indigenous peoples.29 A corporate audit of SGE was undertaken by an external third party in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements for general corporate finance. 
The audit found environmental and social impacts associated with construction and operation of 
geothermal district heating system subprojects typically involve drilling waste management and 
disposal;  tailwater  management  (where  100%  reinjection  is  not  achieved);  inadequate 
occupational  health  and  safety  monitoring  programs;  temporary  non-major  economic 
displacement  during  well  drilling  and  pipe  laying;  and  permanent  non-major  economic 
displacement in case of heat central construction in rural villages.30 The institutional capacity and 
commitment of SGE to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts are deemed 
adequate to meet local and national requirements, but corporate-level capacity development is 
needed to meet the requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
26.  SGE’s  existing  environmental  health  and  safety  system  (EHSS)  is  focused  on  the 
operational environment and health and safety risk management performance of geothermal well 
drilling, pipe laying and heat central operations. The EHSS meets national requirements and the 
International Organization for Standardization 14001 standard.31 The existing system does not, 
however, cover corporate-level environmental and social risk and impact appraisal for new 
concessions, measures for continual improvement (staff training, monitoring and supervision), 
grievance redressal, or reporting to stakeholders such as ADB. A value addition of the project will 
be the establishment of a corporate-level ESMS that will operate in parallel with the operational 
site-level EHSS to meet ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. SGE has committed 
to implement the ESMS prior to first disbursement. An ESMS framework has been designed in 
consultation with ADB, and is being refined with external expert assistance to meet SGE's specific 
business needs and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements.32 
 
27.  The independent audit of SGE's operations found no indications of gender discrimination. 
SGE's  human  resource  policy  broadly  follows  that  of  the  Sinopec  Group,  which  prohibits 
discrimination of any kind, and is compliant with the PRC’s laws and regulations. Approximately 
40% of SGE's 285 direct employees are female, a share slightly above that of the Sinopec Group 
(36%).  Women  hold  approximately  27%  of  managerial  and  technical  positions  at  SGE’s 
headquarters,  including  chief  financial  officer  and  chief  technology  officer;  when  including 
operating subsidiaries, 15% of management and technical positions are held by females. Gender 
equality at SGE is supported by AGE, which, as a member of the United Nations Global Compact, 
subscribes  to  sustainable  and  socially  responsible  policies,  including  the  elimination  of 
discrimination in respect of employment and occupation. In AGE’s management team, two of six 
management positions are held by females. 
 
28.  The  borrowers  will  comply  with  national  labor  laws  and,  pursuant  to  ADB’s  Social 
Protection Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with the internationally recognized core 
labor standards.33 AGE and SGE will report annually to ADB on (i) their (and their contractors’) 
compliance with such laws and (ii) the measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation 
with affected people will be required to be conducted per ADB requirements.34 
 
29 As AGE’s primary focus is its PRC business, which is conducted solely through its shareholding and management 
role in SGE, its safeguards policy compliance appraisal is covered in that of SGE. AGE is bound to all environmental 
and social commitments as agreed upon by SGE.

B.  Anticorruption Policy 
29.  AGE and SGE were advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice 
relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will 
ensure that the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, 
money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism,  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
30.  The proposed loans are within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and single-
project exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
31.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),35 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to AGE and SGE. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the 
proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loans of (i) up to 
$50,000,000 in US dollars to Arctic Green Energy Corporation Private Limited; and (ii) up to 
$200,000,000  equivalent  in  US  dollars  and  yuan  to  Sinopec  Green  Energy  Geothermal 
Development  Company  Limited  (SGE)36 for the  Geothermal  District  Heating  Project  in  the 
People’s Republic of China, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President

metadata.Subject: The project supports private sector participation in urban district heating with geothermal energy in the PRC. By facilitating the delivery of clean and reliable heating services, the project helps mitigate air pollution.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated November 2017 is provided for the ADB project 51186-001 in the People's Republic of China.
